summary: Robert James Dwyer is identified as a Special Agent (SA) of the FBI. He is mentioned in the context of an FBI memorandum from the Miami SAC to the Director, FBI, regarding Pedro Luis Diaz Lanz, Renaldo Blanco Hernandez, and Alberto Eusebio Mojena, dated October 2, 1958. The memorandum encloses a report from SA Robert James Dwyer and a Letterhead Memorandum, with all information provided to the United States Customs Office, Miami, as instructed. The documents suggest Dwyer was involved in gathering and reporting information related to individuals of interest to the FBI, and coordinating with other agencies like the CIA and the United States Customs Office. The documents do not directly link Dwyer to the JFK assassination but show his involvement in intelligence gathering and reporting during the late 1950s and early 1960s.
significance: Robert James Dwyer's significance in the JFK context is indirect. He was an FBI Special Agent involved in intelligence gathering and reporting on individuals of interest. While the provided documents do not directly connect him to the JFK assassination, they illustrate his role in law enforcement and intelligence activities during a period relevant to the events surrounding the assassination.
